Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2007 07:13AM ForTheMoment wrote: Thank you all for your well wishes.  I know you are all right and the time off will do me good.  Just hard to stay calm.  I have so many symptoms, but I think most of them are from this cold, infection that I've been fighting. Kayleigh is feeling much better.  Still a bit of a snotty nose, but her fever is gone and she is in a much better mood.  We are enjoying my parents and being spoiled.  Her Grandpa just took her outside to swing.  They are teaching her to throw the ball for their dog, etc.  So cute!! Love watching her play with them.  Her eyes just light up when either one of them walk into the room.  So neat. I think, while I have been feeling sick, I've also been feeling sorry for myself.  I've been tired, hurt all over, sick, but I think a lot of that has been depression.  I'm trying to get a new attitude and get myself out of bed, get out and enjoy the beautiful fall weather, etc.  I think I get into this downward spin when I don't feel well, and if I let myself, I'll stay there and forget to get out of bed.  That is no way to beat cancer.. So, here I go again.. dust myself, get up and suck it up.  Or, as I used to say when I was training horses..cowgirl up. Thanks again to everyone for responding.  I say it often, but so nice to not feel alone.
Posts.Title: Scanic attack.. :) ForTheMoment katie11

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2007 05:41PM ForTheMoment wrote: Count me in, too!  Whatever we can do.  Mad as hell doesn't even begin to express what I think we all feel.  Lets wake some people up!!
Posts.Title: Bimmer, I told Oprah GeetasMom GEECH

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2007 09:10AM ForTheMoment wrote: Let me start with this... HUGE hugs... Like the others have said.. you couldn't have known, and I really really doubt he was hiding it because of your own sickness.  While kids have huge hearts, I don't think they can hide physical pain any better than we can.  You took him as soon as you noticed anything.  A lot of people would have waited even longer thinking the fever, etc. would clear up.  You are a wonderful mom!  I think all of us mothers have the same thoughts.  Having Kayleigh, while the best blessing in my life, is also the hardest part of this disease.  I cry more tears over worrying about not being there for her when she is sick, not being able to rock her to sleep... than I do anything else.  She is a mommie's girl when she is sad or not feeling well.  Daddy just won't do.  Only mommies hugs and cuddles are acceptable.  While I know, he will do wonderful with her if I am ever gone, I still so strongly feel that she deserves her mommy... ALL OF OUR CHILDREN deserve their mommies... I don't care if they are 2 or 30.  I'm going home next weekend to spend a couple months at my parents home in Iowa and receive my treatments there.  Only because, at 31... I still want my mommy.  I still feel safe in their house, I still find comfort in my mom tucking me in.  I think of all of these things, and hope so much, that Kayleigh has me for as long as she needs me.  Ok.. now I'm rambling.  What I really wanted to say, is we all sooo understand your feelings.  Also, I truly feel sick when I hear people saying "cancer was a gift".. Though I must confess... when I completed treatment when I was Stage 1, and thought it was all behind me, I may have actually uttered those words to people.  Because, like others have said.. cancer did make me appreciate things more, make changes in my life, etc.  Now though... knowing I will never be free of this disease until a miracle, or death... I kick myself for ever saying it.  Almost like the cancer said.. "oh... you think I'm a gift??? Well here you go.. here's some more gift for ya".  Eye opener?.. perhaps.. gift?... piss off.  (for lack of better words) Hugs again.. hope your son is feeling much better, and your spirits are back up! Erin

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2007 04:26PM ForTheMoment wrote: Hi Kimmy- I'm on navelbine as well.  Just got off the avastin as I had progression on it.  The first two weeks of navelbine were really hard on me.  Nausea, very bad  pain in the arm where I received the infusion, insomnia, etc.  However, the last few I have done very well.  Just a bit of insomnia the first night, little arm pain, but I have felt fine.  My hair has thinned a tiny bit, but not enough for anyone else to notice.  That also seems to be slowing down.  Not getting as much out while I shower I was there for a few weeks. Sorry you feel ikcy, but I do think you will get better on it.  It has been pretty easy on me, now that I have adjusted.  Good luck! Love and hugs.. Erin

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2007 03:01AM ForTheMoment wrote: Thanks guys.. they are so much fun.  These are actually labradoodles (half poodle half lab) crossed with a standard poodle.  That makes them second generation, or F1B doodles.  These are the non-shedding, allergy friendly generation.  They get really long fleece coats when adults.  Really pretty.  Anyway to answer your question LuAnn, we sell them.  We started raising them after my first diagnosis because I wanted to do something I loved, rather than just work in the corporate world... had I known it was going to come back at Stage IV, not sure I would have had the guts... glad we did it though... Sure makes me smile when we have pups around. :)
Posts.Title: Fun (non cancer related) news ForTheMoment ForTheMoment

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2007 03:20PM ForTheMoment wrote: Hi Eileen.. :)  Glad you enjoyed the photo..  Yes, it is true, they are hypo-allergenic.  As long as you get a 2nd generation or beyond.  The first cross that is still 50% lab, sheds a bit more and some people have allergy issues.  We raise the 2nd generation which do not shed and are very allergy friendly.  They are tons of fun! :)  I recommend one for your family.. Hope you find the perfect addition. Yes, our daughter loves the pups.  They brighten every day for her.. we constantly hear "puppies... puppies... puppies"

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2007 06:10PM ForTheMoment wrote: First, I'm so sorry to hear this!! Second, did they do a biopsy to confirm it?  With me, I had a very similar rash, pain and all, and they believed it was IBC, but couldn't determine for sure until they did a biopsy.  Instead, they were hoping it was cellulitis and put me on 14 days of antibiodicts.  They drugs didn't start working until around day 10, so I was very nervous, but it did clear up and I've been ok since.  At least in that area, my bones and liver are another story. :)  Anyway, worst case scenerio, it is IBC, A LOT of people do well for years and years with this. Either way, no matter what it is, my thoughts and prayers are with you.  Hang in there and know you are loved. Hugs and love... Erin

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2007 05:56PM ForTheMoment wrote: Hi Tracey- Hope you are feeling more like yourself now.  I've been in a funk for the last couple weeks, too.  (since my last scans)  I think, as others have said, they are just a reminder we have cancer.  My disease had progressed and I had to change treatments, etc.  However, I think even if I showed shrinkage, I'd still go into funk mode around scan time.  Congrats a million times over on the shrinking jerks.  I've started calling my cancer cells jerks, or other not so nice words, rather than cancer.  To me, it makes me feel more in control and gives the Big C a little less hold on me.  Silly.. I know.  We all find our way to get through wherever we can. To me, acting angry with the "jerks" feels better then sad, scared, and out of control.   Huge hugs! Erin
Posts.Title: feeling down tracey2424 joanne1428

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2007 10:26AM ForTheMoment wrote: While I'm so very saddened to hear this news, I don't have the normal horrible sinking feeling that I get when I read one of our sisters has passed.  I think it is because of you Geeta, and Sandy... you have given us such a clear picture of the person that Shelli was, given us such a clear picture of how much she has endured, and given us a clear picture and Shelli's own words that she was ready, really ready.  My heart breaks for her family and her friends, but as others have said, I'm so very happy that she is no longer suffering.  This disease just does not fight fair!!  With a heart as big as Shelli's, no disease should have been able to take her down. Love and hugs... Erin

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2007 06:01PM ForTheMoment wrote: Bimmer- I have not often posted on any of your threads.  Not because I don't absolutely adore you, not because I wasn't praying for a miracle for you, not because I was still thinking she would pull through, but because everything I could have/would have said seemed so inadequate compared to your words and your love for Diane.  I have read every post you have out there, and the responses.  I just couldn't find any words to express what I was feeling.  Now that she is "gone", and in a better place, words feel even more inadequate, but yet I must say something.  Godspeed to Diane, and peace and comfort to your family.  You are both amazing people.  Your love is an inspiration.  Every caregiver should learn their skills and compassion from spending some time with you.  Diane will be greatly missed here, so we really hope you still come back and tell us about what is going on in your life.  Once you get beyond the grieving ( a little ) because I don't think we ever truly do get beyond it, I really hope we hear from you again.  You have a family here. Hugs and love and feeling humbled by you and yours... Erin
Posts.Title: Very advanced B.C.: Diane's final gift. Bimmer ilenee

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2007 11:57AM ForTheMoment wrote: I pretty much just have my oncologist.  He takes care of everything from my depression pills to antibiodicts if I seem to have some infection.  However, he does like me to follow up with a Primary care physician if needed.  I just rarely do.  I have to see my onc so often, I just bring up anything going on in those appointments, generally, he addresses the issues.

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2007 11:30AM ForTheMoment wrote: Hi.. Erin here.  I' ve not been posting as much since we are in Iowa with family, dealing with a litter of 5 week old puppies (fun and crazy at the same time) Also, of course our daughter keeps me very busy.... However, to update everyone... my treatments are going ok.. On only navelbine and Zometa now.  Have my next scans on November 19th.  I've been feeling a lot better, trying to walk 30 minutes a day, my spirits have been lifted (probably partially to effexor, partially due to exercise, etc.) I truly believe this treatment is working, because I'm feeling better than I've felt in a long time.  I do take 800 mg ibuprofen for my bone mets pain which really really works for me.  1 pill every 8 hours, and I wouldn't know I had any pain at all. :) As far as WendyV, I received a PM from her the other day.  Her home modem isn't working, so she has only been checking in from work and doesn't have much time to post.  I can tell you she is feeling great and doing a lot of fun things, living life to the fullest.  Hope to hear from the rest of the MIA's soon! Thanks for posting this Traci... Love and hugs, Erin
Posts.Title: MIA...Missing in Action...Check in please..... Traci-----TripNeg lv2cmp

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2007 12:21PM ForTheMoment wrote: Hi Kenna- Welcome to the club... None of us want to be here, but it is such a warm place to fine support.  I have bone and liver mets, found in January 07.  I have had progression a couple times, stable a couple times, etc.  I'm on my second chemo now and hoping for some good results.  My point is, there are sooo many drugs/options out there.  This is no time to give up hope and read stats.  This is the time to put your game face on and fight like crazy.  That being said, every one of us that have been diagnosed go through the scared, crying at the drop of a hat, screaming rage fit times... have those.. then move on.  Have them again and again if you need to.  I guess like the saying goes, just get up, one more time than you fall down. Love and hugs... Erin

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2007 08:20AM ForTheMoment wrote: You and your family are in my thoughts and prayers! Don't lose hope.
Posts.Title: prayers needed for my mom Douglass LANEF

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2007 08:51PM ForTheMoment wrote: Joanne- That is a beautiful story!  You  must be so proud of the progress she has made.  And yes, it makes perfect sense that she didn't want you to need help.  None of us want to need help, can only imagine what it must be for our loved ones, especially our children.  They so desperately want us to be ok, that they just try to make it so.  I find that a lot of my family tries to just ignore the facts.  They like to live in denial as much as possible.  The only one that truly sees that I DO need help is my other half.  He gets it.  He is with me 24/7 and sees my ups and downs.  He knows when I need help and provides it.  Everyone else still wants to believe I'm healthy enough to "do it all".  Hard, but I know they mean well.  Again, thank you for sharing such a touching story.  Love and hugs, Erin
